case_count_quote: In our case, the patient was diagnosed with DPM
presenting_symptoms_quote: diagnosed with diffuse pulmonary nodules incidentally via CT angiogram chest during inpatient admission for COVID-19 infection
diagnostic_method: Bronchoscopy with bronchioalveolar lavage (BAL) with transbronchial cryo biopsy
diagnostic_method_quote: underwent bronchoscopy with bronchioalveolar lavage (BAL) with transbronchial cryo biopsy of lung nodules
imaging_findings: Numerous sub 6 mm bilateral centrilobular GGNs and solid pulmonary nodules with mild upper lobe predominance
imaging_findings_quote: CT scan chest 1 year later showed numerous sub 6 mm bilateral centrilobular GGNs and solid pulmonary nodules with mild upper lobe predominance
histopathology_quote: transbronchial cryo biopsy of lung nodules, which showed MPMNs
treatment_quote: decision was made for close follow-up with serial CT scans
outcome_quote: given the complexity of the case, lack of symptoms, and stability of nodules
comorbidities: Ductal hyperplasia of the breast, common variable immunodeficiency syndrome (CVID), asthma, obstructive sleep apnea, and thyroid follicular cancer
comorbidities_quote: history of ductal hyperplasia of the breast, common variable immunode /uniFB01 ciency syndrome (CVID), asthma, obstructive sleep apnea, and thyroid follicular cancer
filename: Virk et al. - 2023 - RIDDLE ME THIS A RARE CASE OF DIFFUSE PULMONARY MENINGIOTHELIOMAS.pdf
extraction_notes: The case is well-documented with clear quotes supporting most extracted information. Lab values were available but not included as they were part of the diagnostic workup rather than final findings. The outcome is listed as stable based on the decision for observation and mention of stability of nodules.

case_count_quote: A2-cm pulmonary nodule was incidentally discovered on screening chest radiographs in a 55-year-old nonsmoking Japanese woman.
patient_age_quote: A2-cm pulmonary nodule was incidentally discovered on screening chest radiographs in a 55-year-old nonsmoking Japanese woman.
patient_sex_quote: A2-cm pulmonary nodule was incidentally discovered on screening chest radiographs in a 55-year-old nonsmoking Japanese woman.
presenting_symptoms_quote: A2-cm pulmonary nodule was incidentally discovered on screening chest radiographs
diagnostic_method: Chest radiographs, HRCT, contrast-enhanced chest CT, fiberoptic bronchoscopy with cytology, surgical pathology
diagnostic_method_quote: Both highresolution CT (HRCT) and routine contrast-enhanced chest CT were obtained (10-mm collimation; WL: -500; WW: 2,000) for staging suspected lung cancer... Fiberoptic bronchoscopy was performed with cytologic examination of material obtained from the dominant tumor in the right upper lobe, suggesting malignancy. A right upper lobectomy was performed
imaging_findings: 2-cm spiculated nodule in right upper lobe with inhomogeneous enhancement and irregular border, surrounded by ground-glass opacity. Additional tiny nodules of ground-glass attenuation (1-3 mm) in right upper lobe.
imaging_findings_quote: The nodule was seen in the right upper lobe and showed inhomogeneous enhancement and an irregular border with fine spiculation. The nodule was surrounded by a zone of ground-glass opacity... tiny nodules of ground-glass (1-3 mm in diameter) attenuation in the right upper lobe
histopathology: Well-differentiated adenocarcinoma (papillary subtype) as main tumor, with additional minute pulmonary meningothelial-like nodules (MPMNs) consisting of cellular proliferations of meningothelial-like cells with round to oval nuclei and indistinct cell borders
histopathology_quote: The pathologic diagnosis of the main tumor was well-differentiated adenocarcinoma, papillary subtype... The small nodules seen elsewhere in the right upper lobe were found to represent minute pulmonary meningothelial-like nodules (MPMNs). These lesions consisted of cellular proliferations of meningothelial-like cells with round to oval nuclei and indistinct cell borders associated with venules
immunohistochemistry: Previous studies showed MPMNs are immunoreactive for EMA, vimentin, myosin; negative for cytokeratin, S-100 protein, neuron-specific enolase, and actin
immunohistochemistry_quote: Gaffey et al. (2) reported that meningothelial-like nodules were immunoreactive for epithelial membrane antigen (EMA) and vimentin and were negative for cytokeratin, S-100 protein, neuron-specific enolase, and actin... Torikata and Mukai (3) reported positive immunoreactivity for myosin and vimentin in all meningothelial-like nodules.
treatment_quote: A right upper lobectomy was performed with the assumption that the patient had stage IA (T1N0M0) lung cancer.
outcome: Stable - no change in remaining nodules at 12 months follow-up
outcome_quote: The lesions showed no change in morphologic characteristics of the ground-glass nodules. Although the lesions seen in the other lobes were not sampled histologically, they were stable for an additional 6-month period.
comorbidities_quote: Laboratory evaluation showed an elevated carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) (16.6 ng/mL; normal value: <4.7 ng/mL)
filename: Kuroki et al. - 2002 - Minute Pulmonary Meningothelial-like Nodules High-Resolution Computed Tomography and Pathologic Cor.pdf
extraction_notes: The case is well documented with clear imaging, pathological findings and follow-up. The only uncertainty is around the complete immunohistochemistry profile as this was referenced from previous studies rather than directly performed on this patient.

case_count_quote: A 63 year old female presented for incidentally discovered pulmonary nodules.
patient_age_quote: A 63 year old female presented for incidentally discovered pulmonary nodules.
patient_sex_quote: A 63 year old female presented for incidentally discovered pulmonary nodules.
presenting_symptoms_quote: she denied any respiratory complaints including dyspnea, cough or sputum production
diagnostic_method_quote: transbronchial biopsies revealed many meningothelial like bodies confirming the diagnosis of Diffuse Pulmonary Meningotheliomatosis
imaging_findings: Innumerable and diffusely distributed nodules up to 4mm in a military type pattern, no mediastinal or hilar adenopathy
imaging_findings_quote: The Computed Tomography (CT) scan of the chest with contrast showed innumerable and diffusely distributed nodules up to 4mm in a military type pattern. There was no mediastinal or hilar adenopathy
histopathology: Many meningothelial like bodies confirming Diffuse Pulmonary Meningotheliomatosis
histopathology_quote: transbronchial biopsies revealed many meningothelial like bodies confirming the diagnosis of Diffuse Pulmonary Meningotheliomatosis
outcome_quote: Positron Emission Tomography/Computed Tomography (PET/CT) scan of our patient did not reveal abnormalities suggestive of underlying malignancy.
comorbidities: 10 pack-year smoking history, occupational chemical fume exposure
comorbidities_quote: Medical, social and family history was remarkable for a 10 pack-year smoking history and occupational chemical fume exposure, working in a compounding pharmacy.
filename: Gleason - 2016 - Meningotheliomatosis A Rare Cause of Diffuse Miliary Pattern Pulmonary Opacities.pdf
extraction_notes: All key information is clearly stated in the text with direct quotes available. The case appears to be well documented with clear diagnostic, imaging and histological findings. Treatment information is not explicitly mentioned in the text.
